questions.text: Match the below options as labelled in the given Image to their definitions given by Schaffer system: Select the correct answer from the given below ciode:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

A-1, D-4, E-5 The Shaffer system records the angle in degrees between two imaginary lines tangential to the inner surface of the trabeculae and the anterior surface of the iris, about one-third of the distance from its periphery.

Highyeild:

The system assigns a numerical grade to each quadrant of the angle.

Random:

Explanation for all options: - Grade 4 (35–45°) is the widest angle, characteristic of myopia and pseudophakia. The ciliary body can be visualized without tilting the lens. Grade 3 (25–35°) is an open angle in which the scleral spur is visible. Grade 2 (20°) is an angle in which the trabeculae but not the scleral spur can be seen. Grade 1 (10°) is a very narrow angle in which only the Schwalbe line and perhaps the top of the trabeculae can be identified.

Extraedge:

A slit angle is one in which there is no obvious iridocorneal contact but no angle structures can be identified. Grade 0 (0°) is closed due to iridocorneal contact. Indentation will distinguish appositional from synechial angle closure.

questions.text: A 49-year-old diabetic female comes to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe eye pain with ipsilateral headache, redness and loss of vision. She was in the movie theater with her friends when this episode occurred. Her visual acuity is measured to be 6/60. On examination there is circumcorneal congestion, corneal edema and a shallow anterior chamber. Medical history is significant for her being a type A personality. Which of the following should be preferred for adequate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: All lens matter must be evacuated.

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Intravenous Mannitol Acute or congestive angle - closure glaucoma is caused by a sudden occlusion of the entire angle with a resultant acute rise of intraocular pressure to extremely high levels. Patients complain of a severe unilateral headache and diminution of vision in a ‘red’ eye. Nausea may be frequently associated. On examination, ciliary and conjunctival congestion , corneal oedema, a shallow anterior chamber, and iris bombé with a vertically oval, mid-dilated pupil are present.

Highyeild:

The first drug to be administered in a case of acute ACG (angle closure glaucoma) is IV Mannitol or oral Acetazolamide . This helps to reduce the lOP by dehydrating and reducing the vitreous volume. Following this, pilocarpine eye drops are used to constrict the pupil and break the acute angle closure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option : A . Treatment of lens - induced glaucoma is by extraction of the lens after lowering of the intraocular pressure by medical therapy. All lens matter must be evacuated. Insertion of a posterior chamber intraocular lens is not contraindicated. If not treated early, the outflow channels may be damaged, and long-term glaucoma medications or even glaucoma surgery may be required to control a chronically raised intraocular pressure. Option : C . Secondary angle - closure glaucoma may occur due to a pupillary block, following posterior synechiae to the intraocular lens or vitreous phase, and consequent bowing forwards of the iris. Mydriatics are used to break early posterior synechiae; however, if this is unsuccessful, it is mandatory to do a large Nd:YAG laser iridotomy or even multiple iridotomies to open loculated pockets of aqueous, after controlling the initial rise of intraocular pressure with medications. Postoperative pupillary block is commonly seen in diabetics. However, since this patient has an acute presentation with a classic history (middle aged female, symptoms started while watching a movie, Type A personality and clinical findings; the diagnosis of primary acute angle closure glaucoma is more appropriate. Option : D . Neovascular glaucoma is due to the presence of neovascularization over the iris (rubeosis iridis) and consequent fibrosis , leading to zip-like adhesions of the iris to the cornea at the angle. Anti - VEGF agents and retinal photocoagulation or cryotherapy are used to eliminate the stimulus for neovascularization. The raised intraocular pressure can then be alleviated by a trabeculectomy in conjunction with anti-fibroblastic agents or an anterior chamber drainage implant.

Extraedge:

Pilocarpine is the definitive drug for Acute ACG. Finally, when the conjunctival oedema has resolved, the patient has to undergo laser iridotomy to prevent such attacks in future. A laser has to be done in the fellow eye also as the disease is bilateral. Hence, laser iridotomy is the definitive management of Acute ACG

questions.text: The most reliable provocative test for angle closure glaucoma is ?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dark room test Primary angle closure glaucoma Mechanism - Relative pupillary block (opposition of pupillary margin against lens surface in a mid dilated pupil) causes obstruction of aqueous flow from PC to AC, resulting in iris bomber formation Anterior iris bowing due to increased aqueous pressure in PC causes iridotrabecular corneal contact leads to peripheral anterior synechiae formation resulting in PACG( central deep AC, peripheral shallow AC) Risk factors - Hypermetropia Small cornea Shallow AC Relative anterior position of lens - iris diaphragm Females are more prone It gets precipitated by dim light, stress ,near work, mydriatic Clinical features- Subacute ACG C/ o transient BOV Colored halos around light ,due to corneal epithelial edema Patients have shallow AC, and these symptoms occur more often at night ,due to precipitating factors Acute ACG / acute congestive glaucoma Symptoms Severe pain radiates along trigeminal nerve and may be associated with nausea,vomiting, profuse sweat Redness Sudden LOV ,BOV Chronic ACG PAS may be seen on gonioscopy- usually broad based, causing angle closure more than 180° Creeping angle closure- circumferential, slow spread of synechiae closure form periphery towards schwalbe line Visual field central nasal step is most commonly seen Provocative test - Prone dark room test In this baseline IOP is measured and the patient is made to lie prone in the darkroom for 1 hr. He must be awake, after 1 hr IOP is again recorded. An increase in IOP of more than 8 mm Hg is considered as diagnostic.

Highyeild:

Treatment IV mannitol 1- 2 g/ kg ,25% solution over 30 mins is the DOC Acetazolamide 250 mg 2 tab stat Glycerin orally 1 - 1.5 g/kg body weight Pilocarpine 1% or 2% drops is DOC acts by opening the angle Following which assess corneal activity of clear do laser iridotomy if hazy proceed to peripheral iridoplasty,laser pupillo plasty.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Homatropine mydriatic test Parasympatholytic agents . Atropine 5–1%, homatropine 2%, cyclopentolate 0.5–1%, and tropicamide 1% are all commonly used agents to dilate the pupil and cause cycloplegia . Option: B . Mydriatic - miotic test Mydriasis may contribute to the possible development of angle closure glaucoma due to its effect on “narrow angles” of the eye. Option: C. Water drinking test The water-drinking test (WDT) is used as a provocative test for assessing the outflow facility of aqueous humour in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma. Choroidal expansion is a suggested mechanism of IOP elevation in WDT.

Extraedge:

Signs of ACG IOP is markedly raised from 40 mm Hg to 60 mm Hg. On digital tonometry, rock hard eye Conjunctival hyperemia circumcorneal congestion Eclipse sign: shadow on nasal iris due to iris bombe Pupil: vertically oval ,mid dilated, fixed due sphincter pupillae paralysis caused by raised IOP corneal edema shallow AC with aqueous flare Sectoral iris atrophy with posterior synechiae Glaukomflecken: anterior capsular opacities due to lens epithelial ischemia or necrosis Visual field constriction of the superior field

questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to a severe, right-sided headache that started two hours ago. The pain is centred around the right eye and is associated with nausea and vomiting. She is also seeing halos around lights. The patient has never had a headache like this before. The medical history is notable for hypertension and urinary incontinence. Her medications include valsartan and tolterodine, and she has also been taking trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole for the last 2 days for a urinary tract infection. Her family history is notable for her migraine headaches. The patient does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs. Vital signs are within normal limits. A physical examination shows a red right eye with a nonreactive, dilated pupil. Excessive lacrimation is present. Visual acuity is decreases. Laboratory results show an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 35 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Acute Angle-Closure Glaucoma This patient has acute angle-closure glaucoma (ACG) , presenting with headache, eye pain, nausea, and decreased visual acuity. ACG is characterized by narrowing of the anterior chamber angle, leading to decreased aqueous outflow and elevated intraocular pressure (IOP). The incidence is higher in women (especially those over 40), Asian and Inuit populations, and individuals with farsightedness. Sudden angle closure can then occur due to pupillary dilation from anticholinergic medications (e.g., tolterodine), sympathomimetics, or low ambient light. Examination findings in ACG include conjunctival injection, corneal edema, palpable firmness of the eyeball, and a fixed, mid-dilated pupil.

Highyeild:

Sulfonamides (e.g., trimethoprim sulfamethoxazole) can occasionally trigger ACG due to swelling of structures (eg, lens, retina, choroid) in the posterior chamber.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Cluster headaches can cause acute periorbital pain, conjunctival injections, and lacrimation. However, it is more common in young men and typically causes short-lived (minutes), recurrent attacks associated with autonomic symptoms (eg, miosis, lacrimation). Nausea / vomiting, and a fixed, mid dilated pupil are unexpected. Option: C. Migraine can cause headaches, nausea, and visual disturbances. However, it usually presents in adolescence or early adulthood, and this patient's red eye and nonreactive pupil are more consistent with ACG. Option: D. Giant cell ( temporal ) arteritis (GCA) presents in patients aged 50 with unilateral headache and can cause decreased visual acuity due to anterior ischemic optic neuropathy . However, vomiting and conjunctival erythema are not typical. Although an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) is sensitive for GCA, this test can be elevated in numerous other conditions (e.g., urinary tract infection), and older patients commonly have values above the reported laboratory reference.

Extraedge:

In patients predisposed to ACG, the lens is located more forward against the iris, which impairs the normal flow of aqueous humour through the pupil into the anterior chamber, thereby increasing IOP.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male was referred due to a significantly high IOP and family history of glaucoma. He reports the presence of vision loss. On the pupil exam, RAPD was ruled out. The exam findings are shown in the image below. Which one of the following visual field patterns will most quickly progress to loss of fixation?

options.label: B
options.text: A large superior nasal step encroaching on fixation (<10 degrees)

options.label: C
options.text: Superior and inferior nasal steps encroaching to 20 degrees

options.label: D
options.text: Split fixation to the I4e isopter

questions.correct_answer: D. Split fixation to the I4e isopter
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Split fixation to the I4e isopter The given case history and findings point towards the diagnosis of glaucomatous optic neuropathy secondary to angle closure glaucoma.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . Visual acuity (VA) is likely to be normal except in advanced glaucoma. Always exclude a relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD). If initially absent but develops later, this constitutes an indicator of substantial progression. Option: B . Visual symptoms will usually be absent, unless damage is advanced. The image depicts ultrasound biomicroscopy (UBM) of the anterior segment, showing a closed angle. Option: C : Split fixation is the presence of visual field loss that comes close to fixation.

Extraedge:

A typical pattern of progression is Loss near fixation (paracentral scotoma) to Split fixation to Loss of fixation Thus, the eye at greatest risk is not one with a 5-degree central field , but one with a split-fixation in the horizontal meridian.

questions.text: A 61-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of headache, nausea, blurred vision, and pain in the left eye. She has had similar symptoms in the past. Her vital signs are within normal limits. The left eye is red and is hard on palpate. The left pupil is mid-dilated and nonreactive to light. Administration of which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Epinephrine This patient has a unilateral red, hard, severely painful eye with a mid-dilated, nonreactive pupil, as well as frontal headaches, vomiting, and nausea. These features are consistent with acute angle - closure glaucoma Epinephrine is an alpha - adrenergic and beta - adrenergic receptor agonist. Epinephrine is used topically to treat open-angle glaucoma because alpha-1 receptor stimulation induces vasoconstriction and subsequently decreases aqueous humour production. Alpha-1 receptor agonism also causes pupillary dilation (mydriasis), which decreases the iridocorneal angle and subsequently decreases aqueous humour outflow.

Highyeild:

In individuals with angle-closure glaucoma, such as this patient, mydriasis can rapidly increase intraocular pressure and lead to permanent loss of vision. Therefore, epinephrine is contraindicated for this patient.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Timolol , a nonselective beta blocker, is commonly used in the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma because the inhibition of beta - 2 receptors decreases aqueous humour production and leads to contraction of the ciliary muscle. This process increases the pore size of the trabecular meshwork and subsequently increases aqueous outflow. Timolol should be avoided by individuals with asthma, COPD, or a heart block. Option: C. Apraclonidine , an alpha-2 agonist, is commonly used to acutely reduce intraocular pressure because it decreases aqueous humour production. Apraclonidine is a component of the treatment regimen for individuals with acute angle-closure glaucoma and would be indicated in this patient. This alpha-2 agonist should be avoided in individuals with hypersensitivity to apraclonidine or clonidine and in patients taking MAO inhibitors. Option: D. Acetazolamide reduces aqueous humour production via carbonic anhydrase inhibition and is often given in conjunction with other medications for the treatment of acute angle-closure glaucoma. Acetazolamide should be avoided in individuals with sulfa drug allergies, cirrhosis, or severe hypokalemia.
